label: BODY

text: the fact that reality is always multifaceted and

text: why many disciplines from natural sciences

label: BODY

text: botany, zoology and meteorology and a
label: BODY

text: number of sister disciplines in social sciences

text: such as economics, history, sociology, political

text: science, anthropology, etc. study different
label: BODY

text: aspects of the earth’s  surface. Geography is
label: BODY

text: different from other sciences in its subject
label: BODY

text: matter and methodology but at the same time,
label: BODY

text: it is closely related to other disciplines.
label: BODY

text: Geography derives its data base from all the
label: BODY

text: natural and social sciences and attempts their
label: BODY

text: synthesis.
label: BODY

text: We have noted that there exist variations
label: BODY

text: over the surface of the earth in its physical as
label: BODY

text: well as cultural environment. A number of
label: BODY

text: phenomena are similar and many are dissimilar.

text: as the study of
label: BODY

text: . Thus,
label: BODY

text: geography was perceived to study all those
label: BODY

text: phenomena which vary over space.

text: Geographers do not study only the variations
label: BODY

text: in the phenomena over the earth’s surface
label: BODY

text: (space) but also study the associations with
label: BODY

text: the other factors which cause these variations.
label: BODY

text: For example, cropping patterns differ from
label: BODY

text: region to region but  this variation in cropping
label: BODY

text: pattern, as a phenomenon, is related to
label: BODY

text: variations in soils, climates, demands in the
label: BODY

text: market,  capacity of the farmer to invest and
label: BODY

text: technological inputs available to her/him.
label: BODY

text: Thus, the concern of geography is to find out
label: BODY

text: the causal relationship between any two
label: BODY

text: phenomena or between more than one
label: BODY

text: phenomenon.
label: BODY

text: A geographer explains the phenomena in
label: BODY

text: a frame of cause and effect relationship, as it
label: BODY

text: does not only help in interpretation but also
label: BODY

text: foresees the phenomena in future.

label: BODY

text: Generative agents leverage a large language model to power their
label: BODY

text: behavior. The key observation is that large language models encode
label: BODY

text: a wide range of human behavior from their training data [
label: BODY

text: ]. If
label: BODY

text: prompted with a narrowly defined context, the models can be used
label: BODY

text: to generate believable behavior. Recent work has demonstrated
label: BODY

text: the efficacy of this approach. For instance, social simulacra used a
label: BODY

text: large language model to generate users that would populate new
label: BODY

text: social computing systems to prototype their emergent social dynam-
label: BODY

text: ics [
label: BODY

text: ]. This approach used a prompt chain [
label: BODY

text: ] to generate
label: BODY

text: short natural language descriptions of personas and their behaviors
label: BODY

text: as they appear in the system being prototyped. Other empirical
label: BODY

text: studies have replicated existing social science studies [
label: BODY

text: ], political
label: BODY

text: surveys [
label: BODY

text: ], and generated synthetic data [
label: BODY

text: ]. Large language
label: BODY

text: models have also been used to generate interactive human behavior
label: BODY

text: for users to engage with. In gaming, for instance, these models have
label: BODY

text: been employed to create interactive fiction [
label: BODY

text: ] and text adventure
label: BODY

text: games [
label: BODY

text: ]. With their ability to generate and decompose action
label: BODY

text: sequences, large language models have also been used in planning
label: BODY

text: robotics tasks [
label: BODY

text: ]. For example, when presented with a task, such
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: where the bottle is located and picking it up.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: GENERATIVE AGENT ARCHITECTURE
label: H1

text: Generative agents aim to provide a framework for behavior in an
label: BODY

text: open world: one that can engage in interactions with other agents
label: BODY

text: and react to changes in the environment. Generative agents take
label: BODY

text: their current environment and past experiences as input and gener-
label: BODY

text: ate behavior as output. Underlying this behavior is a novel agent ar-
label: BODY

text: chitecture that combines a large language model with mechanisms
label: BODY

text: for synthesizing and retrieving relevant information to condition
label: BODY

text: the language model’s output. Without these mechanisms, large
label: BODY

text: language models can output behavior, but the resulting agents may
label: BODY

text: not react based on the agent’s past experiences, may not make
label: BODY

text: important inferences, and may not maintain long-term coherence.
label: BODY

text: Challenges with long-term planning and coherence remain [
label: BODY

text: even with today’s most performant models such as GPT-4. Because
label: BODY

text: generative agents produce large streams of events and memories
label: BODY

text: that must be retained, a core challenge of our architecture is to
label: BODY

text: ensure that the most relevant pieces of the agent’s memory are
label: BODY

text: retrieved and synthesized when needed.

text: We introduce a second type of memory, which we call

text: a

label: H1

text: . Reflections are higher-level, more abstract thoughts

text: generated by the agent. Because they are a type of memory, they
label: BODY

text: are included alongside other observations when retrieval occurs.
label: BODY

text: Reflections are generated periodically; in our implementation, we
label: BODY

text: generate reflections when the sum of the importance scores for the
label: BODY

text: latest events perceived by the agents exceeds a threshold (150 in
label: BODY

text: our implementation). In practice, our agents reflected roughly two
label: BODY

text: or three times a day.

text: The first step in reflection is for the agent to determine what
label: BODY

text: to reflect on, by identifying questions that can be asked given the
label: BODY

text: agent’s recent experiences. We query the large language model with
label: BODY

text: the 100 most recent records in the agent’s memory stream (e.g.,
label: BODY

text: “Klaus Mueller is reading a book on gentrification”, “Klaus Mueller is
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: library is currently unoccupied”) and prompt the language model,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: H1

text: Generative agents, both as individual agents and as groups, aim
label: BODY

text: to produce believable behavior based on their environment and
label: BODY

text: experiences. In our evaluation, we investigate the capacity and
label: BODY

text: limitations of generative agents. Do individual agents properly
label: BODY

text: retrieve past experiences and generate believable plans, reactions,
label: BODY

text: and thoughts that shape their behavior? Does a community of
label: BODY

text: agents demonstrate information diffusion, relationship formation,
label: BODY

text: and agent coordination across different pockets of the community?
label: BODY

text: We evaluate generative agents in two stages. We begin with a
label: BODY

text: more tightly controlled evaluation in this section, where we individ-
label: BODY

text: ually assess agent responses to understand whether they generate
label: BODY

text: believable behavior in narrowly defined contexts. Then, in our end-
label: BODY

text: to-end analysis of the agent community over two full game days,
label: BODY

text: we investigate their emergent behavior as a collective, as well as
label: BODY

text: errors and boundary conditions.
label: BODY

text: Evaluation Procedure
label: BODY

text: To assess generative agents in Smallville, we take advantage of
label: BODY

text: the fact that generative agents will respond to natural language
label: BODY

text: questions. So, we “interview” agents to probe their ability to re-
label: BODY

text: member past experiences, plan future actions based on their expe-
label: BODY

text: riences, react appropriately to unexpected events, and reflect on
label: BODY

text: their performance to improve their future actions. To respond to
label: BODY

text: these questions properly, the agents must successfully retrieve and
label: BODY

text: synthesize information. Our dependent variable is the
label: BODY

text: believabil-
label: H1

text: ity
label: BODY

text: of the behavior, a central dependent variable in prior work on
label: BODY

text: agents (e.g., [10]).

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: tion of yourself” or “Describe your typical weekday schedule

label: BODY

text: derstanding of their core characteristics.

text: Future Work and Limitations
label: BODY

text: In this work, we introduced generative agents and presented an
label: BODY

text: initial implementation and evaluation of their architecture. Future
label: BODY

text: research can build upon the proposed agent architecture to improve
label: BODY

text: and further evaluate its performance. In terms of implementation,
label: BODY

text: the retrieval module, for example, could be enhanced to retrieve
label: BODY

text: more relevant information given a context by fine-tuning the rele-
label: BODY

text: vance, recency, and importance functions that compose the retrieval
label: BODY

text: function. Additionally, efforts can be made to improve the archi-
label: BODY

text: tecture’s performance, making it more cost-effective. The present
label: BODY

text: study required substantial time and resources to simulate 25 agents
label: BODY

text: for two days, costing thousands of dollars in token credits and tak-
label: BODY

text: ing multiple days to complete. To enhance real-time interactivity,
label: BODY

text: future work can explore parallelizing agents or developing lan-
label: BODY

text: guage models specifically designed for building generative agents.
label: BODY

text: In general, with advances in underlying models, we believe that
label: BODY

text: agents’ performance will improve.
label: BODY

text: In terms of evaluation, the assessment of generative agents’ be-
label: BODY

text: havior in this study was limited to a relatively short timescale and
label: BODY

text: a baseline human crowdworker condition. While the crowdworker
label: BODY

text: condition provided a helpful comparison point, it did not represent
label: BODY

text: the maximal human performance that could serve as the gold stan-
label: BODY

text: dard in terms of believability. Future research should aim to observe
label: BODY

text: the behavior of generative agents over an extended period to gain a
label: BODY

text: more comprehensive understanding of their capabilities and estab-
label: BODY

text: lish rigorous benchmarks for more effective performance testing.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, varying and contrasting the underlying models, as
label: BODY

text: well as the hyperparameters used for the agents during future sim-
label: BODY

text: ulations, could provide valuable insights into the impact of these
label: BODY

text: factors on the agents’ behavior. Lastly, the robustness of generative
label: BODY

text: agents is still largely unknown. They may be vulnerable to prompt
label: BODY

text: hacking, memory hacking—where a carefully crafted conversation
label: BODY

text: could convince an agent of the existence of a past event that never
label: BODY

text: occurred—and hallucination, among other issues. Future research
label: BODY

text: can comprehensively test these robustness concerns, and as large
label: BODY

text: language models become more resilient to such attacks, generative
label: BODY

text: agents can adopt similar mitigations.
label: BODY

text: In general, any imperfections in the underlying large language
label: BODY

text: models will be inherited by generative agents. Given the known bi-
label: BODY

text: ases of language models, generative agents may potentially exhibit
label: BODY

text: biased behavior or stereotypes. Moreover, like many large language

text: Ethics and Societal Impact
label: BODY

text: Generative agents, while offering new possibilities for human-
label: BODY

text: computer interaction, also raise important ethical concerns that
label: BODY

text: must be addressed. One risk is people forming parasocial relation-
label: BODY

text: ships with generative agents, even when such relationships may not
label: BODY

text: be appropriate. Despite being aware that generative agents are com-
label: BODY

text: putational entities, users may anthropomorphize them or attach
label: BODY

text: human emotions to them [
label: BODY

text: ]. While this tendency may increase
label: BODY

text: user engagement, it also poses risks, such as users becoming overly
label: BODY

text: reliant on or emotionally attached to the agents [
label: BODY

text: ]. To mitigate
label: BODY

text: this risk, we propose two principles. First, generative agents should
label: BODY

text: explicitly disclose their nature as computational entities. Second,
label: BODY

text: developers of generative agents must ensure that the agents, or the
label: BODY

text: underlying language models, are value-aligned so that they do not
label: BODY

text: engage in behaviors that would be inappropriate given the context,
label: BODY

text: for example, reciprocating confessions of love.
label: BODY

text: A second risk is the impact of errors. For example, if a ubiqui-
label: BODY

text: tous computing application makes the wrong inference about a
label: BODY

text: user’s goals based on generative agent predictions, it could lead to
label: BODY

text: annoyance at best and outright harm at worst. In our instantiation
label: BODY

text: of generative agents, we mitigate these risks by focusing on an
label: BODY

text: interactive video game environment, where such harms are un-
label: BODY

text: likely. However, in other application domains, it will be important
label: BODY

text: to follow best practices in human-AI design [
label: BODY

text: ] to understand
label: BODY

text: errors and how they might percolate into the user experience.
label: BODY

text: Third, generative agents may exacerbate existing risks associated
label: BODY

text: with generative AI, such as deepfakes, misinformation generation,
label: BODY

text: and tailored persuasion. To mitigate this risk, we suggest that plat-
label: BODY

text: forms hosting generative agents maintain an audit log of the inputs
label: BODY

text: and generated outputs. This would enable the detection, verifica-
label: BODY

text: tion, and intervention against malicious use. While logging alone
label: BODY

text: cannot directly prevent such misuse, it can reduce the likelihood of
label: BODY

text: motivated actors engaging in this behavior, as the risk of disclosure
label: BODY

text: would be higher. Additionally, building this architecture oneself
label: BODY

text: can be time-consuming (in our case, roughly a year), which may
label: BODY

text: deter some actors from pursuing such behavior by using their own
label: BODY

text: generative agent infrastructures.
label: BODY

text: A fourth risk is over-reliance: the concern that developers or
label: BODY

text: designers might use generative agents and displace the role of
label: BODY

text: humans and system stakeholders in the design process [
label: BODY

text: ]. We
label: BODY

text: suggest that generative agents should never be a substitute for
label: BODY

text: real human input in studies and design processes. Instead, they
label: BODY

text: should be used to prototype ideas in the early stages of design when
label: BODY

text: gathering participants may be challenging or when testing theories
label: BODY

text: that are difficult or risky to test with real human participants. By
label: BODY

text: adhering to these principles, we can ensure that the deployment of
label: BODY

text: generative agents in the wild is ethical and socially responsible.

label: H1

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY
